quotes.quote: Ecstasy should not be viewed as an unusual experience, but rather a natural experience â€“ feeling all of the living matrix of existence around us.

There is an ecstasy that marks the summit of life, and beyond which life cannot rise. And such is the paradox of living, this ecstasy comes when one is most alive, and it comes as a complete forgetfulness that one is alive.
Ecstasy is from the contemplation of things vaster than the individual and imperfectly seen perhaps, by all those that still live.
The ecstasy is so short but the forgetting is so long.

It was then that the ecstasy and the dream began, in which emotion was the matter of the universe, and matter but an adventitious intrusion likely to hinder you from spinning where you wanted to spin.
Any real ecstasy is a sign you are moving in the right direction.
Find ecstasy within yourself. It is not out there. It is in your innermost flowering. The one you are looking for is you.
You will find inner ecstasy when you can be reckless in love.

There is no other greater ecstasy, no other greater blissfulness, than to know who you are. To know the inner space is to know all. It is unlimited silence but not dead, it is alive with songs of its own, with dances of its own.
With the happiness, ecstasy and power you gain from meditation, you can gradually remove your mind from the things it has become hooked to that cause it pain.
Ecstasy carries you completely outside your ego boundaries. In ecstasy you know yourself as cosmic ego, unbounded in time and space.
Ecstasy is a glass full of tea and a piece of sugar in the mouth.
The helpless ecstasy of loosing himself in her charm was a powerful opiate rather than a tonic.
An ecstasy is a thing that will not go into words; it feels like music.
Ecstasy is the energy of spirit. When life flows, ecstasy is natural.
The highest ecstasy is the attention at its fullest.
True ecstasy is stepping out of the bondage of the time-bound, space-bound world. We long to be free of fear and limitation. We hunger to experience our infinite, unbounded Self.
This is the very ecstasy of love, whose violent property ordoes itself and leads the will to desperate undertakings.
Religious ecstasy is a madness of thought freed of its bodily bonds, whereas in the ecstasy of love, the forces of twin natures unite, blend and embrace one another.
Ecstasy is not simply joy. Ecstasy is an emotion of great complexity that hovers almost on the edge of terror sometimes.
Ecstasy is not really part of the scene we can do on celluloid.

Ecstasy is a complex emotion containing elements of joy, fear, terror, triumph, surrender, and empathy. What has replaced our prehistoric understanding of this complex of ecstasy now is the word comfort, a tremendously bloodless notion. Drugs are not comfortable, and anyone who thinks they are comfortable or even escapist should not toy with drugs unless they're willing to get their noses rubbed in their own stuff.
Find ecstasy in life; the mere sense of living is joy enough.
Ecstasy is the accurate term for the intensity of consciousness that occurs in the creative act.
Ecstasy can be painful when it's intense enough, when the kundalini surges enough. The ecstasy is so complete, it's overwhelming sometimes.
